definition: to blow/to play a wind instrument/to blast/to puff/to boast/to brag/to end in failure/to fall through

sentences.english: The referee didn't blow his whistle at all and Nani actually looked at him to check.
sentences.chinese: 裁判沒有吹哨，納尼看着裁判想確認狀況。

sentences.english: Why can't the world come to an end?
sentences.chinese: 什麼東西能跑不能走，會吹哨不會說話？

sentences.english: STAY PUT and blow whistle if lost.
sentences.chinese: 如果走失了，原地待著，吹哨子。

sentences.english: The referee is whistling for a penalty.
The policeman was now blowing his whistle, and that sound brought other constables.
sentences.chinese: 那個警察於是吹哨子，哨音招來了其他警察。

sentences.english: The gimp went lamely around while whistling, informed us not to go to work.
sentences.chinese: 那個瘸子一瘸一跛地四處吹哨，通知說不出工。

sentences.english: The policeman whistled us to stop .
sentences.chinese: 警察吹哨子令我們停止。

sentences.english: "Easy, " says Ivan. "You stand in front of a cave and whistle.
sentences.chinese: “簡單，”伊凡說，“你站在一個洞前並吹哨子。

sentences.english: The policeman whistled them to stop.
The shepherd whistles and sends the dog instructions from a distance.
sentences.chinese: 牧羊人從遠處吹哨子，向狗發出指令。

sentences.english: The referee whistles a technical fault for the digging player.
sentences.chinese: 運動員在防守過程中由於違例而被裁判吹哨。

sentences.english: I stood, in front of a cave and whistled, " Sergei replies.
sentences.chinese: 我站在一個洞前並吹哨子，”謝爾蓋回答說。

sentences.english: Do all the boys in your shop drop their tools the moment the whistle blows?
sentences.chinese: 你車間裏的小夥子們在吹哨時一塊放下工具嗎？

sentences.english: The teacher piped the pupils down after doing drills.
sentences.chinese: 做完操之後，教師吹哨讓學生解散。

sentences.english: It is time to pipe the sailors down.
sentences.chinese: 該是吹哨讓海員們停工的時候了。

sentences.english: He piped  all hands on deck.
sentences.chinese: 他吹哨子召集全體海員到甲板上。

definition: to walk/to step/pace/traveling (walking with the ball, a foul in basketball)
to break the rules/an illegality/a foul
to open fire/to shoot a gun
failed/busted/to have not succeeded/to have died/to have parted company/to have chilled (of a relationship)
open ball (math.)/to start a ball game/to kick off (soccer)/to tee off (golf)
to boo or jeer (as a sign of displeasure at an actor)
shouting and screaming (idiom); to scream loudly/to rant/to kick up a racket/to conduct vigorous propaganda
